awd_titl_txt: Scholarships and Enhanced Mentoring to Support Graduation of Students in Science and Mathematics
awd_abstract_narration:
The NSF Scholarships in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (S-STEM) program supports the retention and graduation of high-achieving, low-income students pursuing STEM degrees. This S-STEM project at Northern Illinois University will provide scholarships and enhanced mentoring to support graduation of students in biological sciences, chemistry and biochemistry, computer sciences, geosciences, mathematics, or physics. Over a period of five years, the project will select forty-six Scholars from the population of rising juniors and transfer students from Illinois' community college system.  This community college system is the third-largest in the country, serving more than one million students each year. Student support will feature a mentoring structure centered around student cohorts and student-faculty pairs, augmented by research opportunities. Student cohorts will meet regularly and will be guided by experienced faculty, near-peer, industrial, and government laboratory mentors. This project has the potential to increase understanding of the personal and institutional circumstances that affect students' participation in academic activities and persistence to degrees in STEM fields. 

This project aims to advance understanding of the role that multiple evidence-based, high impact practices play in improving persistence and graduation of upper-division STEM students. The project leverages existing infrastructure (including NSF STEP and REU programs) and offers students a mentoring program that includes faculty-student pairs, access to research experiences, and weekly cohort meetings to help students achieve their goals and reach their highest academic potential. The program is structured to support students' self-efficacy and science identity, as well as to build essential skills for technical and professional development (i.e., time management, task prioritization, scientific literacy, critical thinking, scientific writing and speaking, leadership, and resume writing). Students will also network with alumni and leaders from industrial, government, and academic laboratories to support the next steps in their professional development. Qualitative research guided by Social Cognitive Career Theory will generate knowledge about the personal and contextual factors, both internal and external to the university, that lead to persistence of economically disadvantaged students in science and mathematics.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Building Engagement in Laboratories, Networking, and Peer Groups in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (BELONG in STEM) program in the College of Liberal Arts and Sciences at Northern Illinois University has been a transformative force for 50 talented, low-income undergraduate students in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) over the past six years. This initiative has provided financial support through annual $5,000 scholarships and fostered a vibrant community that empowers students to thrive academically and professionally. Students connected with STEM faculty to discuss their progress every semester and engaged in monthly events featuring industry professionals and skill-building workshops. Weekly small group meetings led by graduate student mentors created a supportive environment where scholars built meaningful relationships and a sense of belonging. The impact has been remarkable: participants have achieved higher grades and graduated at impressive rates compared to their peers. All scholars rated the program highly, recognizing the invaluable interactions with fellow students and faculty. They emerged more confident, with essential professional skills and a clearer understanding of their identity as STEM students. The intellectual merits of this work were to generate knowledge about how high-achieving, low-income STEM students experience and perceive social support. Through interviews and focus groups, the program revealed the profound effect of peer groups in cultivating a strong sense of community and identity. This was especially crucial for transfer and commuting students, who found connections and support that enriched their college experience. The broader impacts of this project were to provide financial, academic, professional, and social support for 50 low-income STEM students to facilitate their persistence in STEM careers. Indeed, the project has not just supported these low-income STEM students in their education; it has ignited their passion for pursuing fulfilling careers. Many have continued their journeys into graduate studies, embodying their commitment to STEM. The insights gained from this initiative shed light on how community and support can foster confidence and persistence, paving the way for a brighter future for these scholars in their STEM careers.


Last Modified: 04/08/2025
Modified by: Ralph A Wheeler
